title: How to Make a Holiday Centerpiece Using a Metal Bucket

steps.headline: Determine your centerpiece style before gathering supplies.
steps.description: Do you want an offbeat, funky centerpiece or are you looking for something more traditional and refined? Having an idea of style will help you best determine what supplies you’ll need.

steps.headline: Consider access to certain items.
steps.description: Perhaps where you live you have no access to certain items like pinecones or birch tree limbs. Especially if you want to work with native or found items, you may need to consider what you have easy access to and can be intuitively integrated into your motif.

steps.headline: Create a mock centerpiece.
steps.description: In many cases you’ll never know if the centerpiece will really work unless you produce a “pretend” or mock centerpiece. Even if you don’t have the supplies, either sketch or assemble (using other items) a centerpiece that takes into consideration weight, height and girth.

steps.headline: Determine what type of steel bucket or container you’d like to use.
steps.description: Craft stores offer an endless number of containers or adorable metal buckets in a variety of colors so once you’ve identified your style, visualize or select the centerpiece bucket.

steps.headline: Hunt for “found items.” Part of what makes this centerpiece unique is that you can integrate items found in nature or within your home.
steps.description: Take a nature walk and pick out rocks, minerals or vegetation that won’t wither or wilt quickly.

steps.headline: Hit the craft or home store for items like ribbon, decorative flourishes (such as faux flowers, ornaments etc.).
steps.description: Use complimentary colors and finishes that enhance and adhere to your design scheme. Also, consider lighting such as clear colored twinkle lights to add (many strands are battery operated).

steps.headline: Select the right bucket or container to hold your centerpiece.
steps.description: Choosing the ideal bucket is vital to the centerpiece design and decoration. Make sure the bucket is large enough to hold all of your items, but not too big that it overpowers the table.

steps.headline: Fill the bucket with newspaper or filler so that your items will sit at the top of the bucket and on display.
steps.description: If you are going to include items that need to sit at the bottom of the bucket (like a tree branch, etc.) make room so that you can fit the piece on the bottom.

steps.headline: Add longest/largest piece first and then work around that focal point.
steps.description: If you have large, protruding items, add them first to the bucket and then  you can build around them.

steps.headline: Build natural items around each other and add touches of holiday magic.
steps.description: For example, if you include a few protruding birch tree branches, surround the branches with pine cones and embed small twinkling lights around the pine cones to add sparkle.

steps.headline: Add final touches after the basic elements are in place.
steps.description: The smallest, special touches should be added after your structure has been created. This includes touches of glitter, lights or small berries.

text: Visualize Your Centerpiece Determine your centerpiece style before gathering supplies. Do you want an offbeat, funky centerpiece or are you looking for something more traditional and refined? Having an idea of style will help you best determine what supplies you’ll need. Consider access to certain items. Perhaps where you live you have no access to certain items like pinecones or birch tree limbs. Especially if you want to work with native or found items, you may need to consider what you have easy access to and can be intuitively integrated into your motif. Create a mock centerpiece. In many cases you’ll never know if the centerpiece will really work unless you produce a “pretend” or mock centerpiece. Even if you don’t have the supplies, either sketch or assemble (using other items) a centerpiece that takes into consideration weight, height and girth. Determine what type of steel bucket or container you’d like to use. Craft stores offer an endless number of containers or adorable metal buckets in a variety of colors so once you’ve identified your style, visualize or select the centerpiece bucket. Gather Supplies Hunt for “found items.” Part of what makes this centerpiece unique is that you can integrate items found in nature or within your home. Take a nature walk and pick out rocks, minerals or vegetation that won’t wither or wilt quickly. Hit the craft or home store for items like ribbon, decorative flourishes (such as faux flowers, ornaments etc.). Use complimentary colors and finishes that enhance and adhere to your design scheme. Also, consider lighting such as clear colored twinkle lights to add (many strands are battery operated). Select the right bucket or container to hold your centerpiece. Choosing the ideal bucket is vital to the centerpiece design and decoration. Make sure the bucket is large enough to hold all of your items, but not too big that it overpowers the table. Create the Centerpiece Fill the bucket with newspaper or filler so that your items will sit at the top of the bucket and on display. If you are going to include items that need to sit at the bottom of the bucket (like a tree branch, etc.) make room so that you can fit the piece on the bottom. Add longest/largest piece first and then work around that focal point. If you have large, protruding items, add them first to the bucket and then  you can build around them. Build natural items around each other and add touches of holiday magic. For example, if you include a few protruding birch tree branches, surround the branches with pine cones and embed small twinkling lights around the pine cones to add sparkle. Add final touches after the basic elements are in place. The smallest, special touches should be added after your structure has been created. This includes touches of glitter, lights or small berries.
